Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2008 07:13PM sunkistmi wrote: I had 6 nodes removed w/first mast in '06.  I haven't had any problems w/swelling.  The BS said her rate of lymphodema was about 2% and to make sure I put antibiotic on any cuts, no blood pressure or blood draw & garden w/gloves.  She never said anything about flying.  I flew to Alaska 7 weeks after surgery and flew from Anchorage to Fairbanks then back to Anchorage, then home to MI.  No one said anything about a sleeve.  I guess I was lucky I didn't have any problems.  With this new surgery coming up, I asked BS about blood draws & blood pressure on the arm since now the left arm will be off limits too.  She said that after 2 years, it should be fine to use the right arm for procedures.  I hope she is right. What is the sleeve that several of you have spoken of?  Is it like the tight stockings that can be worn to reduce swelling in the legs?  I just wondered because I will be going back to Alaska next summer and want to make sure I have no problems w/swelling.  Thank you in advance for any help. Wendy
Posts.Title: 4 nodes removed - lymphedema risk? BustersMom Deedee79

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2008 02:43PM sunkistmi wrote: In 2006 I was a righty, but now I'm a lefty.  So sorry you are having to go thru the bc itself then deal w/stupid comments.  So far, I've been lucky but that's now a usual thing so I expect the worst at some point.  I've gathered up some great retorts from the sisters' posts.  Now if I can just remember them when I need it.

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2008 08:59PM sunkistmi wrote: Many times when the surgeons send in the tissue from the biopsy or lumpectomy the path report will indicate that the margins are not clean.  Docs want a certain distance on all four sides from the tumor to be free of any cancer cells.  If that doesn't happen, they go back in and cut more out.  Depending on the size of the breast and the possibility of radiation, they can do this either with a lumpectomy or a mastectomy.  It doesn't necessarily mean the cancer has spread, just that they didn't get it all the first time. I was dx with DCIS in 2/06 thru a needle biopsy.  The BS did a lumpectomy and the surgeons took a pretty large chunk of my breast, basically from 9 to noon.  3 of the 4 margins did not come back clean.  The BS said that I would probably not be happy with the look of the breast after further surgery and then radiation.  I most likely would have had to have recon to make it look normal.  I opted to have a mast w/immediate SIEA recon.  For me, it was the best choice.  I was dx w/DCIS in the other breast in May and will be having mast w/immediate TUG recon on Aug. 4. Good luck.  If you would like to talk more, please send me a Private Message and I will be happy to help you however I can.  God bless. Wendy
Posts.Title: Second surgery nack35 nack35

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2008 02:28PM sunkistmi wrote: I had the sentinal node biopsy when they did the lumpectomy.  The BS only took out 4 nodes and they were all clear.  I did not have any drains.  I did go home and work on a quilt, which kept my arms moving.  Maybe moving them helped keep any swelling and drainage down.  Don't know but plan to do the same after the surgery on August 4 after getting home from the hospital.  Course I know I will have drains from the mast & TUG recon. Praying that all will go well with your surgery.
Posts.Title: Second surgery nack35 nack35

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2008 01:44PM sunkistmi wrote: The first time with the rt breastI had to have a biopsy it was with a needle since the lump was 2cm it was very easy to find and hit.  The dr. numbed it very well and the only pain was the burning from the lidocane.  Two weeks ago I had a sterotactic biopsy which was a bit more scary.  For me the hardest part was lying down on the table with the left breast thru a hole.  Because of neck problems, I couldn't turn my head and had to lean on my chin the whole time.  The staff was very nice, but I think they were afraid I was going to move.  The doc was VERY good about explaining everything and making sure I was very numb.  There are people who do not react to lidocaine and must use another form of numbing med.  Once they numbed the outside, as they went deeper they kept injecting more meds.  I did feel the tugging and snapping but there was no pain to speak of.  Even the mammo afterward wasn't painful because she said she wasn't going to compress it was far.  They were wonderful.  However, I would not want to have to go thru it again which since I will be having another mastectomy, will put it out of the picture.  We are the patients and should be able to have a say in the quality of our care.  We have a right to say "STOP".  I know it's hard because we feel so helpless within the situation.  As I write this I can count so many times when I didn't say anything because 'they' are the experts and know what 'they' are doing.  If I had my way, every person dealing with patients would spend 48 hrs being patients themselves.  Perhaps it would teach some of them to be a bit more compassionate.  Good luck my sisters.  Sunkist in MI
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy Pain Estepp suems

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2008 07:01AM sunkistmi wrote: I have been on the patches for the last 3 years for herniated discs.  The dr. told me that it could be a problem when I have surgery because I have developed a tolerance to the med and it would cause me to require more pain meds than usual after surgery.  I let the surgeon know in '06 when I had the mast & recon that I was wearing the patch and they recalibrated what they gave me after surgery.  I did not wear the patch for at least 1 week after due to the other meds they were giving me.  I was told they were not for post-surgical pain, only for chronic pain.  I did not have any other problems once they were willing to work with me.  I usually require more than people think anyway so that is my biggest hurdle.  I'm quite small so they all think that a small amount will work but that's not the case.  The very first surgery I had back in 1971 I was given a dose of Demerol, 100mg IM, and 20 minutes was up walking around.  I only weighed 91 lbs and the nurses said it usually knocked out grown men!  It takes a lot to put me down. Be sure to remove the patch if you are going into a hot tub or sauna because the heat will cause the body to absorb it faster.  You can use adhesive or paper tape to put it back on.  I have such horrible hot flashes that I'm always taping mine back on.  I make really sure I hold my palm over it when I put it on for at least 1 min. even tho it calls for 30 sec.  Also, I found the generic brand much smaller than the brand name.  For me that is important because it can tend to cause itching since I'm allergic to adhesives.  Also, if you have any problems with morphine, you may have a problem with fentenyl since they are in the same family. Good luck with it and don't worry about all the warnings.They have to tell you everything under the sun because of lawsuits but in reality I have felt they were quite safe.  I still use pain pills for breakthrough pain at times.  All the best in your journey. Sunkist in MI
Posts.Title: Switched from my reg meds to Fentanyl Patches scared! snowyday sunkistmi

Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2008 10:20PM sunkistmi wrote: Welcome to this site.  If you work your way through these threads and read what the sisters have written, you may be able to get some answers.  As far as the breast cancer itself, if it is contained to the breast, example, DCIS is cancer that is contained within the milk ducts.  It does not affect anything else.  It can, in time, and no one seems to know how much time, become invasive breast cancer.  At that point, it can go into the lymph system then migrate throughout the body, invading the bone, brain and other organs.  This is called metastasizing. The treatment of the cancer is what causes the problems for the other organs.  I have not experienced this myself since I have DCIS.  I had a mastectomy of the right breast in 2006 and will be having the left breast removed August 4.  My mother had invasive breast cancer and had both radiation and chemo.  Both are very hard on the body, although the chemo is the worst.  Basically it is used to kill all the cancer cells but it kills good cell too.  There can be hair loss, severe vomiting, body pain, fatigue and just general rotten feeling.  Radiation can cause burns, skin changes, fatigue and in some cases if done of the left side, problems down the road with the heart and lung.  If you go to the Treatment thread and ask this question, perhaps you would get some personal stories you could use for your class. One of the other things that affects the body due to the breast cancer, but not the cancer itself, is the reconstruction phase after a mastectomy.  It used to be there were only a couple of procedures, the TRAM flap using a persons own tissue or a implant.  However, new ways of using own tissue are becoming used more often due to easier recovery and less pain.  My first reconstruction used the fat from my stomach, called SIEA.  This next surgery will use the fat from the inner thigh at the top of my leg, a TUG flap.  They can also use the fat on your butt, GAP flap.  If you go to www.diepflap.com, they describe the different types of surgery in detail. I hope this has helped.  I would be happy to talk with you more if needed.  Contact me on the Private Message forum and I will be happy to get back with you.  Good luck on your paper.  I hope you get an A. Sunkist in MI
Posts.Title: effects of breast cancer anatomy101 AnneW

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2008 01:25PM sunkistmi wrote: Dear Stephanie, I am so glad to know you are home.  Our Father answers our prayers doesn't He.  When I become upset at what I am facing, I turn to posts like yours and say a prayer of thanks.  My problems are so SMALL.  My 20 year old son is going thru a crisis of faith and has said that "he can't understand why God gave me cancer again when I go to church and am so 'good'.  My heart aches for him.  I told him that God did not give me cancer again, that I don't know why He allowed it but my job is to continue to pray, to praise Him 'in (not for) all things, and to continue to be the best person I can be, living according to His Word.  I'm not sure if it did any good.  I watch him struggle and I cry, and yet pray that the Holy Spirit would use this opportunity to lead him back. You are such an inspiration and blessing to so many.  I don't know you and have only been on the boards for a month or so but have found such strength and hope in the sisters that have posted.  You are in so many hearts, including mine. I pray that the pain will get better every day and that the lp will reveal nothing serious.  I struggle with tests sometimes, hoping they show nothing yet hoping they show what is so very wrong.  It's almost worse when they come back "OK" but you KNOW in your heart that there is something very, very wrong.  Been thru that several times.  In fact with my thyroid cancer in 1974, three radioactive scans showed absolutely nothing wrong.  The only reason my doc was concerned was because I could start to see a small bump showing and getting larger.  He had never said there was such a thing a thyroid cancer.  Needless to say, it was quite a shock when he came out of the OR and told my family.  It was even more strange since I was only 22.  Usually the variety I had was found only in those older.  The cancer doc walked in my room (my mom was visiting) and stood in front of me; then informed me that "you have thyroid cancer.  We will not be doing any radiation or chemo but will be doing full-body bone scans on you for the next 10 years because it could grow back in your spleen, liver, stomach or bones."  He then turned and walked out.  Here I was, 22 years old and had just gotten married in September (this was June).  I didn't have words to say.  I remember thinking "why me Lord", and that is when I received a hug from God.  I was "enfolded" by Someone so wonderous and heard a voice say "All will be well my child".  I immediately stopped crying and my mother asked me what happened, she said I looked liked I was filled w/light.  I was. I share this because right now I pray that you will be enfolded as I was, to feel God's arms around you because I know you already know you are so very loved.  You are such an inspiration and blessing and have sent out so many prayers to others that it is only right that they come back to you.  May you have a restful evening and a good and peaceful night's sleep. Today, one of my prayers were answered in that I think my mast w/TUG recon looks like it will be scheduled the first week of Aug.  Now I just need to pray for knowledge of peace with the selection of the surgeon.  She was trained by the surgeon that did my SIEA on the rt. breast but I will be her first one alone and here in MI.  Does that make her any less capable?  I don't think so but am second-guessing my decision.  She is in-network and participates w/my insurance and the other surgeon didn't.  We are still paying off the surgery from 2 years ago!  I can't put my family thru that expense again, I felt guilty about it the first time.  I just need to keep praying and asking for peace regarding my decision and for skill for the dr.  She has been doing PS for 15 years and does the other 'normal' forms of breast recon as well as the DIEP/SIEA and TUG recon so I should/will be in good hands. May God bless you and keep you.  May His face shine upon you and His love enfold you and may you rest in Him.  Good night dear sister. Also in His hands, Sunkist in MI
